results:
Based on the web search results, I can provide you with comprehensive information about Dune II, Westwood Studios, its sales figures, and its role in creating the RTS genre that led to Command & Conquer:

## Dune II's Commercial Success and Sales

According to Westwood Studios, Dune II was a commercial success, with global sales in excess of 250,000 units by November 1996.

## Westwood Studios and RTS Genre Creation

While not the first real-time strategy (RTS) video game, Dune II established the format that would be followed for years to come. As such, Dune II is the archetypal real-time strategy game.(no content)While not the first real-time strategy (RTS) game (it was preceded by Herzog Zwei), Dune II established a format that would be followed for years to come, and is the first to use the mouse to move units, giving much fluid interaction. As such, Dune II is the founder of the RTS genre in its modern form.

## Connection to Command & Conquer

Dune II was one of the most influential games in the real-time strategy genre, particularly in Westwood's own Command & Conquer series.(no content)The first game was one of the earliest of the RTS genre, itself based on Westwood Studios' influential strategy game Dune II and introducing trademarks followed in the rest of the series.(no content)Striking a balance between complexity and innovation, it was a huge success and laid the foundation for Age of Empires, Warcraft, Westwood Studios' subsequent strategy game Command & Conquer, and many other RTS games that followed.

## Key RTS Features Established by Dune II

Though not every feature was unique, its specific combination of a fog of war, mouse-based military micromanagement, and an economic model of resource-gathering and base-building became the hallmark of the RTS genre.(no content)It served as the template for subsequent real-time strategy games.

## Development Timeline and Studio History

Dune II: The Building of a Dynasty (also known as Dune II: The Battle for Arrakis in Europe, and simply Dune: The Battle for Arrakis in the Sega Mega Drive/Genesis port) is a Dune computer game, released in 1992 by Westwood Studios.(no content)In 1995, they created their own real-time strategy IP around the idea and mechanics of Dune II, and called it Command & Conquer. Vastly surpassing their sales expectations, the game became a worldwide hit with millions of copies sold, and helped in further popularizing the RTS genre.

The search results confirm that Dune II achieved the 250,000+ sales figure you mentioned and was indeed instrumental in establishing the RTS genre that would later flourish with Westwood's Command & Conquer series.
